text: Patient: I thought, I’ve been thinking about chemo. Doctor: Yeah, I appreciate you thinking about it because I think it warrants Patient: Right. Doctor: thinking about you know. So, there’s standard chemo which is the Taxotere that we chatted about which is that once every three weeks for over an hour. Um the studies that we had talked about there’s probably only one that you’re eligible for which is the chemo plus/minus the high-dose vitamin C but that is a pretty intensive treatment where you’re here twice a week Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: for the whole duration. Yeah, so that’s, in talking to you about that last time Patient: Right. Doctor: that’s just too time consuming especially based on where you guys live and so on. Um but, in reviewing your scans it looks like it’s just all in your bones and not thank goodness in the organs or anywhere else. So, there is a liquid radiation that’s available for patients who have, Healthcare Professional: No its okay, I decided to come on in here. Doctor: We were just talking about radium um which is that liquid radiation that only patients who have stuff in their bones not liver or anywhere else would kind of be the right patient to get that medication and that’s like a one-minute injection that the radiation oncology doctors did once a month Patient: Okay. Doctor: and they do that six months so once a month for six months and that’s been shown to help people live longer and that’s actually FDA approved. So, one could run that through the insurance, you know get treated, and be on your way. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Um. Doctor: Did, uh, did she get tested for it? Family Member: She did not get tested, but Doctor: Okay. Family Member: But, uh, E_’s gonna want to know. Patient: My daughter who just had this, our third grandson, would, I’m sure would want to know. Family Member: I’m sure for E_. Patient: Uh, so we have one granddaughter, E_, and two grandsons. Um. My, my youngest daughter deals with a lot of, uh, medical issues. Um. Uh. Anything else? Doctor: So, my advice, my advice is that um they should all get tested. Because this is a gene that, you know, there’s a lot of genes that we’re doing mutation tests and a lot of them, we don’t even know how predisposing it is to cancer for you - let alone if somebody inherits it. But, this is the one that we know if you have this, it predisposes you to getting cancer. And, that’s why I said, it’s a genie out of the bottle, because some people just don’t wanna know. They don’t wanna know that they’re –- Family Member: Why? Their children! Wouldn’t they want to get tested? Doctor: No, the children don’t want to know? Family Member: They don’t? Doctor: Well. I’m leaving that to you – you’re going to have to have a discussion with them to say, you know.

text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: But my expectation is just to be very honest is that yes, there will be some degree of PSA reduction. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And it may delay the need for hormone therapy for another six months from now with another twelve months from now. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: But I kind of do think that a hormone therapy is sort of inevitable for you. Um the other question that you asked was about using chemotherapy. I presume that you’re asking whether that was either given by itself or maybe in combination with hormone therapy like as a clumped – double therapy. And that we have also done - there have been trials to support that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you know the clinical trials and also the clinical experience do suggest that when you combine standard hormone therapy with chemotherapy or standard hormone therapy with newer type of hormone therapy called (novel) Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. But but again, I don’t want you to go into that thinking that it’s going to increase the chance of a cure. The cure rate is still you know pretty close to zero percent and that it increases the length of time that that systemic therapy works. Patient: Okay. And see, that that that’s my concern at this point. Um you know um you think in terms of the reason I keep pushing hormonal so far back is because I know that’s a proven method - Doctor: Yeah. It is -

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So on the one hand, it does move over time, if the testosterone continues to increase, which it probably will, may feed the cancer. But on the other hand, in the meantime, your quality of life should be better than it would have been with a testosterone let’s say less than twenty. Patient: Okay. That’s’ Doctor: So it’s kind of the choice that we made, and this is sort of the natural expectation of what we were expecting to see. Patient: You would recommend having it done Doc? Doctor: No. There’s no evidence that people like you that people like you in controlling cancer. Patient: You know I was reading an article a while back that I like about it’s going to become common for folks to live into their hundreds. Doctor: Perhaps. Patient: The article mentioned about a miracle drug performing. Metforim. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So I had stashed away and I should be doing this. But I started taking five hundred milligrams Metformin I meant to talk to you the last time I was here. Doctor: Now in the past we because the glucosol Patient: Yes, yes. But we found that to be one of the cholesterol medications I was taking at the time.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
